reviewText: Because his epic musical SHOW BOAT was having rewrite and other technical problems in tryouts, Flo Ziegfeld's 1927 production of RIO RITA was the show that inaugurated the magnificent $2.5 million, 1600-seat Ziegfeld Theatre. It  ran there until the waning days of December, then was relocated to accomodate a streamlined and ready "Show Boat." Due to the revolutionary nature of that Edna Ferber adaptation, "Rita" is one of the last old-style Follies musicals.In its cast were Bert Wheeler and Robert Woolsey, two performers who had never worked together before. A "natural" team, Woolsey (the schemer) wore horn rims and was almost never without a stogie. Wheeler (the innocent) was a curly-haired little guy with a fine tenor voice.Bert and Bob were the only stageshow members to make the transition to film. Following this early talkie's success, RKO offered them a long term contract. In their heyday, Wheeler & Woolsey were as popular as any movie comedians. After 26 features and shorts in 8 years, their cinematic career ended with Robert's death at age 50.W&W;'s finest are the early talkies, especially this play adaptation of RIO RITA (1929), their screen debut. OH! OH! CLEOPATRA (1931) may be the boys' best short. They also made some decent comedies with Mark Sandrich before he began directing Astaire & Rogers musicals. Later works suffered from inferior scripts.Highlight of this frothy musical is a two-strip Technicolor finale. There were originally 16 songs in the 140 minute version of "Rita." This edited re-release is at least 35 minutes shorter. Numbers have been eliminated.Dorothy Lee (late of Fred Waring's Pennsylvanians) subsequently appeared in almost every W&W; movie. Silent era star Bebe Daniels proves here she has a great singing voice, as does her co-star John Boles (Victor Moritz in Universal'sFRANKENSTEIN, from '31). Uncredited dancer Robert Livingston was later a cowboy star in theThree Mesquiteersseries.
summary: Early RKO hit is also Bebe Daniels' first talkie
Title: N/A

reviewText: I am only going to review the print quality; you can read the other review for other useful information.  In this case, just as Warner states, this is an unrestored print and it shows. The picture is fuzzy, the sound is awful.  It may be partly the way it was originally recorded, but at times the background music annoyingly overwhelms the dialogue.  Having an unrestored print with scratchy sound does not help.  Worse still, the sound is about 1/2 second or more late to the picture, and out-of-sync sound-to-image is my pet peeve; it pretty much spoils a film for me.  I made it all the way through the film, which I actually thought was a pretty interesting movie, particularly the Wheeler and Woolsey stuff, but I can't watch it again.  One last thing: during much of the great tap dance scene, Wheeler's legs are cut off, out of the bottom of the frame.  Either the director was a moron or this is horrendous print.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Radio Pictures "RIO RITA" is almost a copy of Flo Ziegfeld's stage success.A couple of slips in the dialogue still remain uncut, as many of the takes are long ones, and presented, I suggest, to maintain flow.The film was a great success in it's day and  played up until the remake by Abbott and Costello in the early 40's.John Boles is in fine form in the leading role with Bebe Daniels mastering a thick hispanic accent, comedy being provided by Bert Wheeler and Robert Woolsey who provide some rather silly routines together with some inovative dance numbers. An inserted number, in what was Act 2 of the show is a show stopper with Dorothy Lee singing and dancing alongside Robert Woolsey.All the musical numbers from the show are there, apart from a Waltz number with John Boles, which was cut from an early 30's re-issue,the song however can still be heard on a preserved recording.The dance numbers, along with wonderful costumes, show what a Ziegfeld show was like, and the Technicolor section,which is all of Act 2, makes such a difference,it's a pity all of the film was not shot in colour.An entertaining escapism and a must for fans of the early film musical.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Rio Rita is an early "talkie" taken from Florenz Ziegfeld's stage play and put onto the big screen. There are several musical numbers mixed in with genuine suspense and an amazing two-strip Technicolor finale that must have thrilled movie-going audiences. Bebe Daniels' Spanish accent is extremely good, too! The choreography and cinematography are well done and the musical score enhances the picture. The film mixes in the comedy team of Bert Wheeler as Chick Bean and Robert Woolsey as Ned Lovett; although their story doesn't tie in well to the main plot they do provide comedy relief and their routines are truly very funny. The sound could have been better so I could hear every word the actors were saying; but then again this was filmed during the days of early sound so I assume this was the best they could do.When the action starts, Captain Jim Stewart and his American posse in Texas are after a notorious Mexican bandit called The Kinkajou; and when Jim is in Mexico he falls for Rita Ferguson (Bebe Daniels) and suspects that her brother Roberto (Don Alvarado) is the bandit himself. Jim wants to bring Roberto to justice but this complicates his love affair with Rita as Rita naturally wants to spare her brother Roberto from being caught. Rita may not be sure that Roberto is The Kinkajou; but she wants to protect her brother even if he is the bandit himself.Of course things get even more complicated. Russian General Ravinoff (Georges Renavent) and his mates are also after The Kinkajou; and Ravinoff doesn't play by the rules, to put it mildly. Moreover, just as Jim Stewart loves Rita, Ravinoff wants Rita for his own bride even though he doesn't love her the way Jim does. At the same time, look for an essentially unrelated subplot that has Chick Bean marrying a young woman named Dolly (Dorothy Lee) after his lawyer Ned Lovett mistakenly tells Chick that his Mexican divorce from his first wife Katie (Helen Kaiser) is a done deal. The rest of the film focuses on how everything turns out for everyone.Look also for a nicely presented finale in Technicolor; I really liked that! Some people will say that the comedy of Bert Wheeler and Robert Woolsey gives the film energy--and I agree with them. Rio Rita is a good production overall; but as is the case with most early "talkies" the sound could have been  better and the acting could have been a bit more convincing. In addition to the sound being a bit disappointing when actors were speaking their lines, there are also one or two "skips" in the sound and film--and the camera could have been used somewhat more effectively especially when Bert Wheeler was tap dancing (his feet are sometimes cut off when he dances); a good restoration may be able to enhance at least a few parts of the film. Nevertheless, I did enjoy the picture.I recommend Rio Rita for fans of the actors in it; and anyone who appreciates early "talkies" with musical numbers would do well to add this to their collections. True, the musical number "The Kinkajou" was deleted from this Warner Archives Collection DVD release while one or two other numbers were added for the big screen release (i.e., "You're Always In My Arms" sung by Bebe Daniels); but what we see still gives us an excellent idea of what a Ziegfeld show looked like; and that's grand.
summary: + 1/2 star: a good early musical that deserves to be restored
Title: N/A

reviewText: According to Wikipedia, five reels out of the original fifteen reels of the film are believed to be lost.  Apparently there used to be a complete copy of the film at the Museum of Modern Art in NYC, but it looks to have been either lost or stolen.  Wikipedia also says that the complete soundtrack still survives on Vitaphone discs.  What would be nice would be for Warner Bros. to issue the film including the soundtrack of the missing parts, accompanied, if available, by relevant stills from those missing sections.  Unless and until the print that used to belong to MoMA turns up, that is probably the best we can expect for now.
Title: N/A

reviewText: RKO's filming of this stage hit has all the problems that we laugh at in the later movie Singin' in the Rain. There are sonic dropouts during the dialogue scenes, an at times bizarrely immobile camera, and so on. During "The Rangers' Song," you can clearly see that the soundtrack isn't in synch with the men in the shot: what they're singing isn't what you hear, at least not when they're actually singing it. And this print is missing at least two numbers that were in the original release print. That said, this is a wonderful, crazy film, very faithful to the stage show (there is one new number, "Sweetheart, We Need Each Other") and even including a bit of the original Ziegfeld staging in a showgirl number. The pacing is very zippy, even during the romantic scenes, and that new number provides an extremely funny bit for Wheeler and Woolsey when the two girls sing the tune while the comics trade blows, getting bigger and meaner until...I won't spoil it. But this film is a must for anyone interested in old Broadway musicals and the technical aspect of Hollywood's conversion to sound.
summary: Technically Flawed But a Treat For Students of the Musical
Title: N/A
